trial_identification.studytitle: The Use of Intravenous Fluids in Acute Ureteric Colic
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A prospective, randomised controlled trial on the effect of administration of intravenous fluids compared to minimal fluids on pain scores in acute ureteric colic

interventions.interventions: To receive 1L normal saline intravenously over 2 hours; further intravenous (IV) fluids can be given only with administration of medications. Analgesic medications given at discretion of clinician.
interventions.comparator: IV fluids given only with administration of medications. Analgesic medications given at discretion of clinician.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Time taken to reach a clinically significant difference in median visual analogue pain scores
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured at 60, 120, 180 and 240 minutes post commencement of treatment.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Total amount of narcotic analgesia used
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Taken from the medical record and measured at 60, 120, 180 and 240 minutes post commencement of treatment.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Length of stay in the Emergency Department
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Taken from the medical record and measured in minutes until discharge from Emergency Department or admission to Ward/ Short-Stay Observation Unit

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Adult patients (aged 18 or over) who present to the Emergency Depatment with symptoms of acute ureteric colic
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Patients requiring the acute administration of IV fluids for resuscitation, suspected pyelonephritis, history of congestive cardiac failure, known renal impairment/failure, patients unable to give pain scores (eg. English as a second language, dementia), allergy to non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs

trial_design.concealment: All suitable patients will be identified by the Triage nurse who will notify a member of the research team. Participants will be approached by an investigator not involved in the provision of their medical care. Patients will be randomly allocated to either the experimental (IV fluids) group or control group (no IV fluids) using sealed, sequentially numbered and opaque envelopes.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Acute ureteric colic is the pain caused by the passage of kidney stones. Standard treatment is the administration of pain-relieving medications. Intravenous (IV) fluids may also help relieve pain, may cause further pain or have no effect on pain at all. There is a lack of evidence regarding the impact of IV fluids on pain relief in acute ureteric colic. This study hopes to delineate this role by randomising participants with acute ureteric colic into two groups, both of which reflect current practice. The first group will receive IV fluids at a preset rate; the second group will receive IV fluids only with medications. Pain scores via a visual-analogue scale will be taken hourly for up to four hours; these will then be compared to see if there is any clinically significant difference in the pain scores between the two groups.
